articles.headline: Case Stokes Haiti’s Fear for Children, and Itself
articles.snippet: The Americans who were detained late Friday at the Dominican border with 33 children struck a deep emotional chord in Haiti.
articles.abstract: The Americans who were detained late Friday at the Dominican border with 33 children struck a deep emotional chord in Haiti.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — “God wanted us to come here to help children, we are convinced of that,” Laura Silsby, one of 10 Americans accused of trafficking Haitian children, said Monday through the bars of a jail cell here. “Our hearts were in the right place.”

articles.headline: As Marines Move In, Taliban Fight a Shadowy War
articles.snippet: A joint U.S.-Afghan operation shows how insurgents blend ancient signaling methods with modern weaponry.
articles.abstract: A joint U.S.-Afghan operation shows how insurgents blend ancient signaling methods with modern weaponry.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARARDAR, Afghanistan  The Marine infantry company, accompanied by a squad of Afghan soldiers, set out long before dawn. It walked silently through the dark fields with plans of arriving at a group of mud-walled compounds in Helmand Province at sunrise.

articles.headline: In Europe, Challenges for Google
articles.snippet: On issues like privacy, copyright protection and the dominance of its search engine, Google is increasingly clashing with lawmakers and regulators.
articles.abstract: On issues like privacy, copyright protection and the dominance of its search engine, Google is increasingly clashing with lawmakers and regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google has a problem in China. But it may have bigger headaches in Europe.

articles.headline: Deficits May Alter U.S. Politics and Global Power
articles.snippet: Projections suggest there is virtually no room over the next decade for new domestic initiatives.
articles.abstract: Projections suggest there is virtually no room over the next decade for new domestic initiatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In a federal budget filled with mind-boggling statistics, two numbers stand out as particularly stunning, for the way they may change American politics and American power.

articles.headline: Cloudy Future for Fannie and Freddie
articles.snippet: The Great Bailout is mostly over for the banks. For Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the lifeline keeps getting longer.
articles.abstract: The Great Bailout is mostly over for the banks. For Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the lifeline keeps getting longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Great Bailout is mostly over for the banks. But for those troubled behemoths of the nation’s housing bust, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the lifeline from Washington just keeps getting longer.

articles.headline: Hacking for Fun and Profit in China’s Underworld
articles.snippet: A young hacker let a reporter into his world of trolling for information that may one day be worth money.
articles.abstract: A young hacker let a reporter into his world of trolling for information that may one day be worth money.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANGSHA, China  With a few quick keystrokes, a computer hacker who goes by the code name Majia calls up a screen displaying his latest victims.

articles.headline: Bankers in Davos Seek a United Message on Volcker Rule
articles.snippet: At the World Economic Forum, contentious discussions centered on President Obama’s plan to restrict proprietary trading.
articles.abstract: At the World Economic Forum, contentious discussions centered on President Obama’s plan to restrict proprietary trading.

articles.headline: Flock Is Now a Fight Team in Some Ministries
articles.snippet: Evangelical churches are embracing mixed martial arts in an effort to appeal to young men.
articles.abstract: Evangelical churches are embracing mixed martial arts in an effort to appeal to young men.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS  In the back room of a theater on Beale Street, John Renken, 37, a pastor, recently led a group of young men in prayer.

articles.headline: Curveball Alters Talks on Wall St. Reform
articles.snippet: President Obama’s calls to tax and curb the activities of Wall Street have thrown an unpredictable element into the debate over financial regulatory reform.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s calls to tax and curb the activities of Wall Street have thrown an unpredictable element into the debate over financial regulatory reform.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s proposals to tax and curb the activities of Wall Street have thrown an unpredictable element into the debate over financial regulatory reform. They also have touched off an intensive new round of lobbying and raised questions in Congress over whether his plan will add urgency or merely bog things down.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Lawmakers Ask Toyota to Prove Fix Solves Problem
articles.snippet: A House committee wants documents showing the electronic systems on cars were not at fault.
articles.abstract: A House committee wants documents showing the electronic systems on cars were not at fault.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Lawmakers and the Transportation Department stepped up pressure Tuesday on Toyota, seeking proof that problems that could cause its cars to speed up unexpectedly were limited to floor mats and sticking pedals.
